candidates.title: replace lazy_static with std's OnceLock
candidates.body:
The `once_cell` has been stable in std, and the 'lazy_static' is going to be deprecated, so it's better to use std's `once_cell` instead of `lazy_static`.

check detail at : https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/lazy-static.rs/issues/214

candidates.title: chore(volo-http): do not put meta config in service
candidates.body:
## Motivation

Putting request related config in `MetaServiceConfig` will be difficult to maintain.

In addition, use `Option<Duration>` for timeout interfaces is unnecessary, but it will introduce many breaking changes.

## Solution

Move `timeout` and `fail_on_error_status` from `MetaServiceConfig` into context and when client creates a request, it will clone the config into context.

Revert changes for timeout related interfaces.

candidates.title: chore(volo-http): optimize user experience
candidates.body:
## Motivation

- logs from `volo-http` are confusing
- timeout cannot removed
- type of client with layers are complex

## Solution

- unified log format in `volo-http` with prefix `[Volo-HTTP]`
- adjusted the timeout interface, `Dutation` -> `Option<Duration>`
- add generic types for `DefaultClient`

candidates.title: fix(volo-http): use `Option<CallOpt>` rather than `CallOpt`
candidates.body:
## Motivation

In the previous code, if there was a default `Target` and the request only had a `CallOpt` set, the new `CallOpt` would have no effect because the request had no `Target`.

## Solution

This commit fixes this by replacing `CallOpt` with `Option<CallOpt>`. If we use the default target and there is only one `CallOpt`, we will use it directly, otherwise the target `CallOpt` will be used. If the request target is used, the default `CallOpt` will have no effect.

candidates.title: chore(volo-http): refactor client target
candidates.body:
## Motivation

The previous `Target` implementation was confusing and complicated.

## Solution

We refactored `Target` to support chain calls, which is more elegant and easy to use.

In addition, we removed `TypeMap` and `FastStrMap` in `Target` and added `CallOpt`. Its usage is similar, but it is simpler and more elegant.

```rust
/// A wrapper type with [`FromRequest`] and [`IntoResponse`]
```

Correct usage:

```rust
/// A wrapper type with [`FromRequest`](crate::server::extract::FromRequest) and
/// [`IntoResponse`](crate::server::response::IntoResponse)
```

## Solution

the code change.

candidates.title: fix(volo-build): specify itertools version for volo-build
candidates.body:
## Motivation

We forgot to specify the `itertools` version for `volo-build` before, this may cause `volo-build` failed to build if users are using `itertools` version smaller than `0.13`.

## Solution

Specify the version in `Cargo.toml`.

candidates.title: chore: adjust doc config and improve doc readability
candidates.body:
## Motivation

Previously our documentation was very difficult to read on [`docs.rs`](https://docs.rs/), especially the [`volo-http`](https://docs.rs/volo-http/latest/volo_http/).

This PR improves doc readability through adding some configs and more documents.

## Solution

Add `package.metadata.docs.rs` for all crates:

```toml
[package.metadata.docs.rs]
all-features = true
rustdoc-args = ["--cfg", "docsrs"]
```

Add more documents, especially documents of modules and types.

Method as one field of client context is assigned by user. However, the previous lifetime bound would only receive 'static str, which might be impossible for user, for example, the universal interface platform, which get method from upstream.

## Solution

candidates.title: fix: Enforce faststr versions to fix new_u8_slice_unchecked not found
candidates.body:
## Motivation

faststr raises error like the following during upgrade:

```shell
error[E0599]: no function or associated item named `new_u8_slice_unchecked` found for struct `FastStr` in the current scope
   --> /home/xuanwo/.cargo/registry/src/index.crates.io-6f17d22bba15001f/sonic-rs-0.3.6/src/lazyvalue/value.rs:269:52
    |
269 |             JsonSlice::Raw(r) => unsafe { FastStr::new_u8_slice_unchecked(r) },
    |                                                    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ function or associated item not found in `FastStr`
    |
note: if you're trying to build a new `FastStr` consider using one of the following associated functions:
      FastStr::new
      FastStr::new_inline
      FastStr::from_arc_str
      FastStr::from_string
      and 11 others
   --> /home/xuanwo/.cargo/registry/src/index.crates.io-6f17d22bba15001f/faststr-0.2.11/src/lib.rs:30:5
    |
30  | /     pub fn new<T>(text: T) -> Self
31  | |     where
32  | |         T: AsRef<str>,
    | |______________________^
...
41  |       pub const fn new_inline(s: &str) -> Self {
    |       ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
...
59  |       pub fn from_arc_str(s: Arc<str>) -> Self {
    |       ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
...
65  |       pub fn from_string(s: String) -> Self {
    |       ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
help: there is an associated function `from_u8_slice_unchecked` with a similar name
    |
269 |             JsonSlice::Raw(r) => unsafe { FastStr::from_u8_slice_unchecked(r) },
    |                                                    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

```

## Solution

It's better to raise the version requirement for faststr, so that users don't need to take actions.

candidates.title: chore(volo-http): add panic handler for http server
candidates.body:
## Motivation

Since Volo already supports `catch_panic`, Volo-HTTP should provide some common handlers for easy use.

## Solution

Add two panic handlers, one that always returns `500 Internal Server Error`, and another that returns a fixed payload that implements `IntoResponse` and `Clone`.

candidates.title: feat: support catch panic in service

labels.name: A-volo
labels.description: This issue concerns the main`volo` crate.

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: This is a PR that adds a new feature or fixes a bug.

candidates.body:
## Motivation

Catch panic and handle it is a common need for both http and thrift users.

## Solution

This PR implements a `Service` which catches panics and provides a `Handler` trait for users to handle the panic.

There's also an example `Handler` implementation in `volo-thrift::server:panic_handler`.

candidates.title: feat: don't reuse connection when it closed
candidates.body: Avoid client side `Broken Pipe` error when server already closed the connection in pool.

candidates.title: feat(volo-http): impl IntoResponse for Json and Form
candidates.body:
## Motivation

Previously, there were `impl TryFrom<Json> for Body` and `impl IntoResponse for T where T: TryInto<Body>`, so `Json` was deduced as `impl IntoResponse`. However, `Content-Type` was not inserted in `IntoResponse`, which may cause problems.

## Solution

This PR implements `IntoResponse` for `Json` and `Form`, and inserts `Content-Type` in the header. To avoid compilation issues, `TryFrom<Json<T>> for Body` has been removed. When the client needs to send json, users can call `json` directly without calling `data` and manually inserting the header.

candidates.title: feat(volo-thrift): implement entry message trait for bytes
candidates.body:
## Motivation
Considering the generic client which based on thrift is currently only possible to send and receive `Bytes`, we can implement the `EntryMessage` trait for `Bytes` for ease of use.

## Solution
Implement  the `EntryMessage` trait for `Bytes`:
1. encode: just append the input bytes
2. decode: just return the remaining payload bytes 
3. size: return the size of bytes which need to be encoded

candidates.title: chore(volo-http): refactor Target of discover for more scalability
candidates.body:
## Motivation

#431 has refactored service discover and treat DNS resolver as a service discover for HTTP client, but the previous implementation does not have strong scalability, for example, the `Target` is designed for DNS resolver only.

## Solution

This PR refactored the `Target` and added `TypeMap` and `FastStrMap` for it. In addition, a new param `target_parser` is also added.

For resolving an address, the conversion path is:

1. Parse `str` to `Uri` and build a `Target` from the `Uri`
2. Call the `target_parser` so that it can resolve the `Target` and set necessary information to `Endpoint`
3. The service discover will resolve `Endpoint` to `Address`
4. Access it.

Fixes: #431

candidates.title: fix: add includes for resolving absolute idl path
candidates.body:
```yaml
entries:
  thrift:
    filename: thrift_gen.rs
    protocol: thrift
    repos:
      thrift:
        url: https://github.com/apache/thrift.git
        ref: HEAD
        lock: 9bd1f1bee7bf59080492bbd3213ca1fed57ab4d6
    services:
    - idl:
        source: git
        repo: thrift
        path: test/Service.thrift

    # to solve cases like this or idl contents for include path uses absolute form
    - idl:
        source: git
        repo: thrift
        path: apache/thrift/test/Service.thrift
```

candidates.title: feat(volo-build): support deduplication of same item for config builder
candidates.body:
## Motivation
IDL reference might introduce repeated item definition with same namespace, which would lead to the codegen problem of repeated structure definition. Sometimes, it is caused by repeated reference of third-party idls, which can't be changed, and in this case, we should deduplicate these same items for corrected codegen.

## Solution
Under the assumption that the items with same defined name and namespace are completely consistent in semantics, we would only generate the struct definition for the first item in idl.

candidates.title: chore(volo-http): refactor service discover related codes
candidates.body:
## Motivation

The DNS resolver is coupled in `Client`, which is not elegant enough and may have an impact on other service discovers.

And the previous caller name mode and callee name mode are confusing, which should also be refactored.

## Solution

This commit refactors service discover related codes, including DNS resolver and names of caller and callee.

First, this commit removes caller name mode and callee name mode, we use target address (host name or address) as callee name by default, and use name with version of crate as caller name by default. The `caller_name` and `callee_name` from `ClientBuilder` can override those default configs.

And this commit makes DNS resolver as a service discover, which can decoupling client with DNS resolver, and it can also be replaced to a dummy service discover for disabling DNS resolver, or replaced to a customized service discover.

## Break Changes

### Remove `caller_name_mode` and `callee_name_mode`

This PR removed `caller_name_mode` and `callee_name_mode`, it is expected that most users will not be affected.

In the latest implementation, if `caller_name` or `callee_name` are empty, the default names will be used, otherwise they will override the default names.

### Use `https` rather than `scheme` for setting scheme, host and port

Because we supports only HTTP and HTTPS (in other words, with or without TLS), `scheme` may be confusing.

In this PR, we updates the first argument of `scheme_host_and_port` from `scheme: Option<Scheme>` to `https: bool`, users who using it will be affected.

For adapting it, just replace your `None` or `Some(Scheme::HTTP)` to `false`, and `Some(Scheme::HTTPS)` to `true`.

## Future Works

The current implementation does not have strong scalability, for example, the `Target` is designed only for DNS resolver, and it is useless for other service discovers.

We will refactor the `Target` later for better scalability.

candidates.title: bugfix(volo-http): add unit tests and fix bugs for dns and tls
candidates.body:
## Motivation

This PR adds some unit tests for the HTTP client, which exposed some bugs during testing.

First, `hickory_resolver::Resolver` is a synchronous resolver, and `Resolver::resolve` is a synchronous function, but it uses `Runtime::block_on` of `tokio::runtime::Runtime`, which will **PANIC** when it is within scope of tokio runtime.

Additionally, the config `disable_tls` should prevent HTTPS requests from being sent, but in the previous implementation, when `disable_tls` was set, the client would send it as an HTTP request.

## Solution

This PR removes the dependency on the synchronous resolver from `hickory_resolver`, which means we don't resolve the hostname when building the client, rather than resolving it when the request is sent, during which the asynchronous resolver is available and will not panic on `Runtime`.

This PR will also cause TLS requests with `disable_tls` to fail with the error `BadScheme`.

candidates.title: fix(volo-build): oneway init service build failed

labels.name: C-bug
labels.description: This is a bug-report. Bug-fix PRs use `C-enhancement` instead.

candidates.body:
## Motivation

Previously, when using `volo init` to init the layout which will generate a default impl for each method, and there's a `oneway` method, it will generate the return value like this:

```rust
... -> Result<volo_gen(), ::volo_thrift::ServerError>
```

This is not intended.

## Solution

This PR fixes this.

candidates.title: fix(volo-cli): modify the local init service path relative to the yml
candidates.body:
## Motivation
The initialization of local idl is based on the raw path, and the modification of relative path is for the volo.yml has moved into the volo-gen dir generated at the init cmd execution path. However, the modification should occur after the initialization but it was actually not.

## Solution
Modify the local service path relative to the yml file after initialization if the given path is relative.

candidates.title: feat(volo-http): support default target for client
candidates.body:
## Motivation

Sometimes we use HTTP client for a fixed target address, this PR adds default target for client, with which client can build a request without setting the target address and send it directly.

In addition, this PR also adds `Target` with its builder.  With them introduced, client and request builder can use a more elegant way for setting target address.

## Solution

1. Support setting target address for `ClientBuilder`
2. Add `TargetBuilder` which can be set to address or hostname and will be resolved to address finally

candidates.title: feat(volo-build, volo-cli): refactor config model and correspond commands
candidates.body:
## Motivation
For the usability of config file, the same git repo for different idls should be managed as one source, and another goal is to reuse the common part of single config and workspace config for better coding.

## Solution
1. Refactor the config model to manage repo unitedly, and extract the common part between the single and workspace config.
2. Support the repo command, including add and update cmd for users manage their repos by cli.
3. Adapt the idl and init command to the new model.

candidates.title: feat(volo-thrift): support biz-error

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: This is a PR that adds a new feature or fixes a bug.

candidates.body:
This PR adds support for the new `BizError` type that can transmit business errors by TTHeader.

On the server side, if user returns `BizError`, it will be automatically inserted into `CommonStats`, and will be encoded in TTHeader.

On the client side, if there's `BizError` in TTHeader, the `MessageService` will return it instead of the original response. This behavior is on by default, but can be opt-out by setting `enable_biz_error(false)` when building client.

candidates.title: chore(volo-http): refactor config of context
candidates.body:
## Motivation

The previous context has an argument `stat_enable` in its `new` function, but it can be set in other ways and setting it in `new` is not a good design.  However, `tls`, in other words, whether tls is enabled should not be changed during processing request, so it is better to set it in `ClientContext::new`.

In addition, in previous codes, we should import `volo::context::Context` for getting `tls` and `stat_enable`, and it is not a good design, too.  It requires a getter or setter function.

## Solution

- `ServerContext::new(target: Address, stat_enable: bool)` -> `ServerContext::new(target: Address)`
- `ClientContext::new(target: Address, stat_enable: bool)` -> `ClientContext::new(target: Address, tls: bool)`
- Add `xxxContext::enable_stat`, `xxxContext::stat_enabled` and `ClientCxInner::tls`

candidates.title: feat(volo-http): support https
candidates.body:
## Motivation

This PR add TLS support for Volo-HTTP

## Solution

candidates.title: feat(volo): improve TLS support
candidates.body:
## Motivation

TLS support in crates used to be confusing, for example, client-side TLS support was in `volo`, while server-side TLS support was in `volo-grpc`, and there is no convenient way to configure it.  In example of gRPC with TLS, `rustls` configuration is wrote manually and there is no example with `native-tls`.

## Solution

This PR moves all TLS related codes to `volo`, and many convenient methods are added, e.g., `TlsAcceptor::from_pem_file` and `TlsConnector::builder` with `TlsConnectorBuilder::add_pem_from_file`.

However, for more complex usage, users still have to configure it themselves.

Additionally, in most cases users do not need to care whether they are using `rustls` or `native-tls`, they can simply select a feature to use it.

candidates.title: feat(volo-thrift): support clone for errors
feat(volo-http): remove connection info, add ext for parts
candidates.body:
## Motivation

The previous `ConnectionInfo` is complex and not versatile enough, and some common functions are missing, e.g. getting host or getting full uri.

## Solution

This PR removed `ConnectionInfo` and add trait `RequestPartsExt` for `http::request::Parts`.  It provides `forwarded` function, which is core of `get_connection_info` without coupling to other parts.  There are also some common functions including `host`, `port`, `scheme`, `request_uri` and `full_uri`.

candidates.title: chore: add selftest script and fix clippy warnings
candidates.body:
## Motivation

`cargo check` can only check for build problems and print warnings, but `cargo clippy` can do what `cargo check` can do, plus check code style. So we can use `cargo clippy` directly in CI.

## Solution

This PR updates commands in GitHub CI.

And this PR also adds a script `scripts/selftest.sh`, it can check for all rules on your device.

In addition, in order to facilitate CI to work properly, the `librustls` has been recovered to its original name `rustls`, and a new private feature `__tls` is added for avoiding complex `#[cfg(any(xxx, xxx))]`.

Please note that `selftest.sh` can only be checked on your device, in other words, on the platform of your device, but GitHub CI can be checked on all platforms, including Linux-x86_64, Linux-aarch64, macOS, and Windows, so the output of the script is for reference only.
